badges.name: EVM
badges.description: This project uses the Ethereum Virtual Machine to run its smart contracts and supports the Solidity programming language

badges.name: Ethereum with blobs
badges.description: This project is posting its data to Ethereum as blobs

display.name: Scroll
display.description: Scroll is ZK Rollup that extends Ethereum’s capabilities through ZK tech and EVM compatibility.

warnings.batchSubmissions: Transaction data batches that have not yet been proven can be reverted.

liveness.explanation: Scroll is a ZK rollup that posts transaction data to the L1. For a transaction to be considered final, it has to be posted on L1, but the owner can revert them if the corresponding root has not yet been confirmed.

inScope: Ability to deposit, spend, and withdraw the gas token (ETH)
Upgradability of L1 and L2 core contracts
notInScope: Upgradability of other external ERC20 token contracts

requirements: Upgrades unrelated to onchain provable bugs provide less than 30d to exit.
The Security Council's actions are not confined to onchain provable bugs.

requirements.description: A complete and functional proof system is deployed.
The project calls itself a rollup.
State roots are posted to Ethereum L1.
Inputs for the state transition function are posted to Ethereum L1.

A source-available node exists that can recreate the state from Ethereum L1 data. Please note that the L2BEAT team has not verified the validity of the node source code. [View code](https://github.com/scroll-tech/go-ethereum)
Users are able to exit without the help of the permissioned operators.
In case of an unwanted upgrade by actors more centralized than a Security Council, users have at least 7d to exit.
The Security Council is properly set up [(List of members)](https://scroll-governance-documentation.vercel.app/gov-docs/content/what-is-security-council).

principle.description: Compromising ≥75% of the Security Council is the only way (other than bugs) for a rollup to indefinitely block an L2→L1 message (e.g. a withdrawal) or push an invalid L2→L1 message (e.g. an invalid withdrawal) with a <7d exit window.

requirements.description: Upgrades unrelated to onchain provable bugs provide less than 30d to exit.
The Security Council's actions are not confined to onchain provable bugs.

contract.description: Custom token escrow with third-party governance, using the canonical bridge only for messaging.
Custom token escrow with third-party governance, using the canonical bridge only for messaging.

query.functionSignature: function finalizeBatchWithProof4844(bytes _batchHeader, bytes32 _prevStateRoot, bytes32 _postStateRoot, bytes32 _withdrawRoot, bytes _blobDataProof, bytes _aggrProof)
function commitBatches(uint8 version, bytes32 parentBatchHash, bytes32 lastBatchHash)

layer.description: The data is posted to Ethereum as calldata or blobs.

bridge.description: The validating bridge has access to all the data, as it is posted onchain.

stateValidation.description: STARKs and SNARKs are zero knowledge proofs that ensure state correctness. STARKs proofs are wrapped in SNARKs proofs for efficiency. SNARKs require a trusted setup.

dataAvailability.description: All of the data needed for proof construction is published on Ethereum L1.

exitWindow.description: There is no window for users to exit in case of an unwanted regular upgrade since contracts are instantly upgradable.

sequencerFailure.description: In the event of a sequencer failure, users can force transactions to be included in the project's chain by sending them to L1. There can be up to a 7d delay on this operation. Proposing new blocks requires creating ZK proofs.

proposerFailure.description: If the Proposer fails, users can leverage the source available prover to submit proofs to the L1 bridge.

dataAvailability.name: All data required for proofs is published on chain
dataAvailability.description: All the data that is used to construct the system state is published on chain in the form of cheap blobs or calldata. This ensures that it will be available for enough time.

references.title: ScrollChain.sol - Etherscan source code commitBatches() function

operator.name: The system has a centralized sequencer
operator.description: While forcing transaction is open to anyone the system employs a privileged sequencer that has priority for submitting transaction batches and ordering transactions.

risks.text: the operator exploits their centralized position and frontruns user transactions.

references.title: ScrollChain.sol - Etherscan source code, finalizeBundlePostEuclidV2() function modifier

forceTransactions.name: Users can force any transaction
forceTransactions.description: Because the state of the system is based on transactions submitted on the underlying host chain and anyone can submit their transactions there it allows the users to circumvent censorship by interacting with the smart contract on the host chain directly. The enforced liveness mechanism is activated if either an L1 message has not been finalized for more than 7d or a batch has not been finalized for more than 7d. When activated, transactions that were directly posted to the smart contract can be forcefully included by anyone on the host chain, which finalizes their ordering.

exitMechanisms.name: Regular messaging
exitMechanisms.description: The user initiates L2->L1 messages by submitting a regular transaction on this chain. When the block containing that transaction is settled, the message becomes available for processing on L1. ZK proofs are required to settle blocks.

references.title: L1ETHGateway.sol - Etherscan source code, finalizeWithdrawETH function

stateDerivation.nodeSoftware: The node software to reconstruct the state is available [here](https://github.com/scroll-tech/go-ethereum). Note that it uses the L2 p2p network to fetch blocks, and not the L1 network. The consistency with L1 data can be checked by running the [scroll-geth node](https://github.com/scroll-tech/go-ethereum) with the `--rollup.verify` flag.
stateDerivation.compressionScheme: Data batches are compressed using the [zstd](https://github.com/facebook/zstd) algorithm.
stateDerivation.genesisState: The genesis file can be found [here](https://scrollzkp.notion.site/genesis-json-f89ca24b123f462f98c8844d17bdbb74), which contains two prefunded addresses and five predeployed contracts.
stateDerivation.dataFormat: Blocks are grouped into chunks, chunks are grouped into batches, and batches are grouped into bundles. Chunk encoding format can be found [here](https://github.com/scroll-tech/scroll-contracts/blob/main/src/libraries/codec/ChunkCodecV0.sol#L5), and batch encoding format can be found [here](https://github.com/scroll-tech/da-codec/blob/main/encoding/codecv7_types.go#L20).

stateValidation.description: Each update to the system state must be accompanied by a ZK proof that ensures that the new state was derived by correctly applying a series of valid user transactions to the previous state. These proofs are then verified on Ethereum by a smart contract.

categories.title: Prover Architecture
categories.description: The prover code can be found [here](https://github.com/scroll-tech/zkvm-prover/tree/master/crates/prover).

categories.title: ZK Circuits
categories.description: Scroll circuits are [OpenVM](https://book.openvm.dev/)-based Guest Programs that use the OpenVM prover. The source code of the base circuits can be found [here](https://github.com/scroll-tech/zkvm-prover/tree/master/crates/circuits).

categories.title: Verification Keys Generation
categories.description: SNARK verification keys can be generated and checked against Ethereum verifier contract using [this guide](https://github.com/scroll-tech/openvm/blob/66a8134a515c9f699d572e7f681311a04df3aef8/book/src/advanced-usage/sdk.md?plain=1#L99). The system requires a trusted setup.

categories.title: Validity proofs
categories.description: Each update to the system state must be accompanied by a ZK proof that ensures that the new state was derived by correctly applying a series of valid user transactions to the previous state. These proofs are then verified on Ethereum by a smart contract.

references.title: ScrollChain.sol - Etherscan source code, verifyAggregateProof() and verifyBundleProof() calls

proofVerification.shortDescription: Scroll is a ZK-EVM rollup on Ethereum.

verifiers.name: PlonkVerifierV0
verifiers.description: Scroll verifier using calldata for DA. Corresponds to version v0.9.5 of the circuits.

verifiers.name: PlonkVerifierV1
verifiers.description: Scroll verifier using blobs for DA. Corresponds to version v0.10.3 of the circuits.

verifiers.name: PlonkVerifierV1-1
verifiers.description: Scroll verifier using blobs for DA. Corresponds to version v0.11.4 of the circuits (Curie upgrade).

verifiers.name: PlonkVerifierV2
verifiers.description: Scroll verifier proving bundles (group of batches). Corresponds to version v0.12.0 of the circuits (Darwin upgrade).

verifiers.name: PlonkVerifierV2-1
verifiers.description: Scroll verifier proving bundles (group of batches). Corresponds to version v0.13.0 of the circuits (Darwin v2 upgrade).

verifiers.name: PlonkVerifierPostEuclid
verifiers.description: Scroll verifier proving bundles (group of batches). Corresponds to openvm zkVM Circuits (Euclid upgrade).

ethereum.name: MultipleVersionRollupVerifier
ethereum.description: Contract used to update the verifier and keep track of current and old versions.

ethereum.name: L1MessageQueueV2
ethereum.description:
Contains the array of queued L1 -> L2 messages, either appended using the L1ScrollMessenger or the EnforcedTxGateway.
* Roles:
  * **admin**: ProxyAdmin

ethereum.name: L1ScrollMessenger
ethereum.description:
Contract used to send L1 -> L2 and relay messages from L2. It allows to replay failed messages and to drop skipped messages. L1 -> L2 messages sent using this contract pay for L2 gas on L1 and will have the aliased address of this contract as the sender.
* Roles:
  * **admin**: ProxyAdmin

ethereum.name: EnforcedTxGateway
ethereum.description:
Contracts to force L1 -> L2 messages with the proper sender.
* Roles:
  * **admin**: ProxyAdmin

ethereum.name: ScrollOwner
ethereum.description:
Owner of all contracts in the system. It implements an extension of AccessControl that manages roles and functions allowed to be called by each role.
* Roles:
  * **opsFast**: TimelockFast; ultimately Scroll Multisig 3
  * **opsNoDelay**: TimelockEmergency; ultimately Scroll Multisig 2
  * **scMinorityNoDelay**: Scroll Security Council Minority
  * **scNoDelay**: TimelockSCEmergency; ultimately Scroll Security Council

ethereum.name: SystemConfig
ethereum.description:
System configuration contract for Scroll, contains enforcedBatchParameters and messageQueueParameters determining permissionless mode.
* Roles:
  * **admin**: ProxyAdmin
  * **owner**: ScrollOwner

ethereum.name: ScrollChain
ethereum.description:
The main contract of the Scroll chain. Allows to post transaction data and state roots, along with proofs. Sequencing and proposing are behind a whitelist unless enforcedBatchMode is activated.
* Roles:
  * **admin**: ProxyAdmin

ethereum.name: TimelockSCEmergency
ethereum.description:
A timelock with access control. The current minimum delay is 0s. Proposals that passed their minimum delay can be executed by the anyone.
* Roles:
  * **canceller**: Scroll Security Council
  * **executor**: Scroll Multisig 1, Scroll Security Council; ultimately EOA 1, EOA 2, EOA 3, EOA 4
  * **proposer**: Scroll Security Council
  * **timelockAdmin**: Scroll Security Council, TimelockSCEmergency; ultimately Scroll Security Council

ethereum.name: TimelockFast
ethereum.description:
A timelock with access control. The current minimum delay is 1d. Proposals that passed their minimum delay can be executed by the anyone.
* Roles:
  * **canceller**: Scroll Multisig 3
  * **executor**: Scroll Multisig 1; ultimately EOA 1, EOA 2, EOA 3, EOA 4
  * **proposer**: Scroll Multisig 3
  * **timelockAdmin**: Scroll Multisig 3, TimelockFast; ultimately Scroll Multisig 3

ethereum.name: TimelockSCSlow
ethereum.description:
A timelock with access control. The current minimum delay is 3d. Proposals that passed their minimum delay can be executed by the anyone.
* Roles:
  * **canceller**: Scroll Security Council
  * **executor**: Scroll Multisig 1, Scroll Security Council; ultimately EOA 1, EOA 2, EOA 3, EOA 4
  * **proposer**: Scroll Security Council
  * **timelockAdmin**: Scroll Security Council, TimelockSCSlow; ultimately Scroll Security Council

ethereum.name: TimelockEmergency
ethereum.description:
A timelock with access control. The current minimum delay is 0s. Proposals that passed their minimum delay can be executed by the anyone.
* Roles:
  * **canceller**: Scroll Multisig 2
  * **executor**: Scroll Multisig 1; ultimately EOA 1, EOA 2, EOA 3, EOA 4
  * **proposer**: Scroll Multisig 2
  * **timelockAdmin**: Scroll Multisig 2, TimelockEmergency; ultimately Scroll Multisig 2

risks.text: a contract receives a malicious code upgrade. There is no delay on code upgrades.

zkProgramHashes.title: Scroll program
zkProgramHashes.description: Proves the correct STF of Scroll L2 before the Euclid upgrade (V2).

zkProgramHashes.title: Scroll program
zkProgramHashes.description: Proves the correct STF of Scroll L2 before the Euclid upgrade (V2).

zkProgramHashes.title: Executable of the Scroll bundle program
zkProgramHashes.description: Proves the correct execution of a bundle of Scroll L2 blocks, which is the unit of L2 state finalisation from L1’s perspective.

zkProgramHashes.title: Config of the Scroll bundle program
zkProgramHashes.description: This is not a ZK program, but a commitment to the config of Scroll bundle program (bundle leaf commitment). It also needs to be checked to verify the expected ZK verification.

zkProgramHashes.title: Executable of the Scroll bundle program
zkProgramHashes.description: Proves the correct execution of a bundle of Scroll L2 blocks, which is the unit of L2 state finalisation from L1’s perspective.

zkProgramHashes.title: Config of the Scroll bundle program
zkProgramHashes.description: This is not a ZK program, but a commitment to the config of Scroll bundle program (bundle leaf commitment). It also needs to be checked to verify the expected ZK verification.

actors.name: Scroll Security Council
actors.description:
A Multisig with 9/12 threshold. 
* Can interact with TimelockSCEmergency
  * cancel queued transactions 
  * execute transactions that are ready 
  * propose transactions 
  * update the minimum delay and manage all access control roles of the timelock [via: TimelockSCEmergency - or - acting directly]
* Can interact with TimelockSCSlow
  * cancel queued transactions 
  * execute transactions that are ready 
  * propose transactions 
  * update the minimum delay and manage all access control roles of the timelock **with 3d delay or with no delay** [via: TimelockSCSlow with 3d delay - or - acting directly]
* Can interact with ScrollOwner
  * disable enforced batch mode [via: TimelockSCEmergency]
  * update and reset the PauseController cooldown period [via: TimelockSCEmergency]
  * update ScrollChain zk proof verifier [via: TimelockSCEmergency]
  * update the L1ScrollMessenger fee vault address [via: TimelockSCEmergency]
  * update the minimum delay message queue parameters and enforced mode parameters [via: TimelockSCEmergency]
  * upgrade all core contracts of the system [via: TimelockSCEmergency]

actors.name: Scroll Multisig 2
actors.description:
A Multisig with 2/4 threshold. 
* Can interact with ScrollOwner
  * pause the ScrollChain in permissioned mode and the L1 -> L2 message queue [via: TimelockEmergency]
  * remove permissioned batchers and provers to the whitelist, and update the sequencer address [via: TimelockEmergency]
  * revert unfinalized batches [via: TimelockEmergency]
* Can interact with TimelockEmergency
  * cancel queued transactions 
  * propose transactions 
  * update the minimum delay and manage all access control roles of the timelock [via: TimelockEmergency - or - acting directly]

actors.name: Scroll Multisig 3
actors.description:
A Multisig with 3/5 threshold. 
* Can interact with TimelockFast
  * cancel queued transactions 
  * propose transactions 
  * update the minimum delay and manage all access control roles of the timelock **with 1d delay or with no delay** [via: TimelockFast with 1d delay - or - acting directly]
* Can interact with ScrollOwner
  * add permissioned batchers and provers to the whitelist **with 1d delay** [via: TimelockFast with 1d delay]
  * set ERC20 gateways in the L1GatewayRouter **with 1d delay** [via: TimelockFast with 1d delay]

actors.name: Scroll Security Council Minority
actors.description:
A Multisig with 3/12 threshold. 
* Can interact with ScrollOwner
  * unpause core contracts via the PauseController

actors.name: EOA 1 and EOA 4
actors.description:
Member of Scroll Multisig 1, Scroll Multisig 4, Scroll Multisig 2.
* Can interact with TimelockSCEmergency
  * execute transactions that are ready [via: Scroll Multisig 1]
* Can interact with TimelockFast
  * execute transactions that are ready [via: Scroll Multisig 1]
* Can interact with TimelockSCSlow
  * execute transactions that are ready [via: Scroll Multisig 1]
* Can interact with TimelockEmergency
  * execute transactions that are ready [via: Scroll Multisig 1]

actors.name: EOA 2
actors.description:
Member of Scroll Multisig 1, Scroll Multisig 2.
* Can interact with TimelockSCEmergency
  * execute transactions that are ready [via: Scroll Multisig 1]
* Can interact with TimelockFast
  * execute transactions that are ready [via: Scroll Multisig 1]
* Can interact with TimelockSCSlow
  * execute transactions that are ready [via: Scroll Multisig 1]
* Can interact with TimelockEmergency
  * execute transactions that are ready [via: Scroll Multisig 1]

actors.name: EOA 3
actors.description:
Member of Scroll Multisig 1, Scroll Multisig 2, Scroll Multisig 3.
* Can interact with TimelockSCEmergency
  * execute transactions that are ready [via: Scroll Multisig 1]
* Can interact with TimelockFast
  * execute transactions that are ready [via: Scroll Multisig 1]
* Can interact with TimelockSCSlow
  * execute transactions that are ready [via: Scroll Multisig 1]
* Can interact with TimelockEmergency
  * execute transactions that are ready [via: Scroll Multisig 1]

actors.name: Scroll Security Council
actors.description:
A Multisig with 9/12 threshold. 
* Can interact with ScrollOwner
  * disable enforced batch mode [via: TimelockSCEmergencyScroll]
  * update ScrollChain zk proof verifier [via: TimelockSCEmergencyScroll]
  * upgrade all core contracts of the system [via: TimelockSCEmergencyScroll]
* Can interact with TimelockSCEmergencyScroll
  * cancel queued transactions 
  * execute transactions that are ready 
  * propose transactions 
  * update the minimum delay and manage all access control roles of the timelock [via: TimelockSCEmergencyScroll - or - acting directly]
* Can interact with AgoraGovernor
  * can configure contract settings such as voting delay, quorum, contract manager **with 3d delay** [via: TimelockSCSlow with 3d delay]

actors.name: Scroll Multisig 2
actors.description:
A Multisig with 2/4 threshold. 
* Can interact with TimelockEmergency
  * cancel queued transactions 
  * propose transactions 
  * update the minimum delay and manage all access control roles of the timelock [via: TimelockEmergency - or - acting directly]

actors.name: Scroll Multisig 3
actors.description:
A Multisig with 3/5 threshold. 
* Can interact with TimelockFast
  * cancel queued transactions 
  * propose transactions 
  * update the minimum delay and manage all access control roles of the timelock **with 1d delay or with no delay** [via: TimelockFast with 1d delay - or - acting directly]

actors.name: GnosisSafeL2
actors.description:
A Multisig with 2/2 threshold. 
* Can interact with AgoraGovernor
  * can propose new onchain governance proposals without the required threshold of votes

actors.name: EOA 5, EOA 6 and EOA 8
actors.description:
Member of Scroll Multisig 1, Scroll Multisig 2.
* Can interact with TimelockSCEmergencyScroll
  * execute transactions that are ready [via: Scroll Multisig 1]
* Can interact with TimelockFast
  * execute transactions that are ready [via: Scroll Multisig 1]
* Can interact with TimelockEmergency
  * execute transactions that are ready [via: Scroll Multisig 1]

actors.name: EOA 7
actors.description:
Member of Scroll Multisig 1, Scroll Multisig 2, Scroll Multisig 3.
* Can interact with TimelockSCEmergencyScroll
  * execute transactions that are ready [via: Scroll Multisig 1]
* Can interact with TimelockFast
  * execute transactions that are ready [via: Scroll Multisig 1]
* Can interact with TimelockEmergency
  * execute transactions that are ready [via: Scroll Multisig 1]

upgradesAndGovernance: All core contracts in the Scroll protocol are upgradable by the `ProxyAdmin`, which is controlled by the Security Council through the `ScrollOwner` contract. The ScrollOwner is a central governance contract controlled by four distinct Timelocks: two governed by the Security Council multisig and two by the Scroll team multisigs. Each multisig can initiate specific types of changes with differing delay guarantees. The team has authority to revert unfinalized batches and add or remove sequencers and provers while sequencing is in permissioned mode. As the ScrollOwner admin, the Security Council can revert the team actions by revoking the team roles in the ScrollOwner contract (through the `TimelockSCSlow`) and upgrading the affected contracts. The Security Council can change parameters that affect L1->L2 messaging and the activation of permissionless sequencing (i.e., enforcedBatchMode), such as by calling the `updateMessageQueueParameters` and `updateEnforcedBatchParameters` functions or by pausing the `EnforcedTXGateway`. Emergency pause of core contracts is managed through the `PauseController`, which allows the team to pause batch commitment and finalization in permissioned mode, as well as L1->L2 messaging. Each pause is subject to a cooldown period of 1mo execution delay, during which the Security Council minority can unpause, while the Security Council majority is authorized to update and reset the cooldown period. SCR token holders perform onchain voting on governance proposals through the `AgoraGovernor` contract on L2. However, onchain governance proposals do not contain transaction payloads, so onchain voting only acts as an onchain temperature check. The Security Council is in charge of executing upgrades.

milestones.title: Scroll Feynman upgrade
milestones.description: Feynman upgrade to improve the fee model and EVM compatibility.

milestones.title: Emergency verifier upgrade
milestones.description: The SecurityCouncil emergency upgrades to fix a bug in the verifier.

milestones.title: Access control upgrade
milestones.description: Scroll Security Council upgrades permissions to regain Stage 1 status.

milestones.title: Emergency upgrade
milestones.description: The SecurityCouncil emergency upgrades to fix a bug in the plonky3-based proof system.

milestones.title: Scroll Euclid upgrade
milestones.description: Scroll becomes Stage 1 by improving permissions and introducing enforced batch mode.

milestones.title: Batches reverted
milestones.description: To fix a bug in the compression, 55 previously committed batches are reverted.

milestones.title: Darwin upgrade
milestones.description: Introduces a reduction in gas fees through bundling multiple batches into a single validity proof.

milestones.title: Curie upgrade
milestones.description: Introduces data compression, new opcodes, dynamic block time, and new transaction types.

milestones.title: Bernoulli upgrade
milestones.description: Introduces EIP-4844 data blobs for L1 data availability, and the SHA2-256 precompile on L2.

milestones.title: Scroll Alpha testnet launch
milestones.description: Scroll launches its Alpha testnet on Goerli.
